Message.Msg: ** President Mohammed Morsi gave Ahmadinejad a red-carpet welcome on the tarmac at Cairo airport** Everything the community organizer attemps in the middle east turns to sheet, another diplmatic triumph. Depose a friendly govrnment and replace it with a Islamic dictatorship...maybe Morsi will lend a few new American fighter jets and Abram tanks to his new found friend Ahmadinejad...you can't make this stuff up! This is the same template Billy Clinton used, ignore all the problems so the folks would like him and saddle the next President with another 9/11. IRAN'S AHMADINEJAD ON HISTORIC VISIT TO CAIRO CAIRO (AP) -- President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad arrived in Egypt on Tuesday for the first visit by an Iranian leader in more than three decades, marking a historic departure from years of frigid ties between the two regional heavyweights. Egypt's Islamist President Mohammed Morsi gave Ahmadinejad a red-carpet welcome on the tarmac at Cairo airport, shaking the Iranian's hand and exchanging a kiss on each cheek as a military honor guard stood at attention. Ahmadinejad's three-day visit, which is centered around an Islamic summit, is the latest sign of improved relations between the countries since the 2011 uprising ousted Egypt's longtime ruler President Hosni Mubarak and brought an Islamist government to power in Cairo. Such a visit would have been unthinkable under Mubarak, who was a close ally of the U.S. and shared Washington's deep suspicions of Tehran.

Message.Msg: black thugs. To bad old Bloomberg didn't run a super bowl ad denouncing this kind of behavior...to busy with banning sodas and guns. Flash Mob Mayhem: Violent Groups Of Teens Leave NYC Businesses In Ruins NEW YORK (CBSNewYork) — Violent, thieving mobs have been making headlines across the country for the past few years, and now they have hit New York City. And Maurice Dubois reported in this CBS 2 investigation, the teen mobs have left neighborhoods worried as businesses take matters into their own hands. Judson Bennett, 78, recently ran into a violent group of teens – often described with the once-benign term “flash mob” – as he made his daily trip to buy a newspaper at his favorite news team. “I’m approaching the newsstand, and then suddenly there is a tremendous force behind me,” Bennett said. Bennett ended up with a broken arm. “I was taken completely by surprise,” he said. In New York and across the country, the mobs of kids – 20, 30, 40 or more — appear out of nowhere and suddenly charge a newsstand or convenience store. They ransack, steal and wreak havoc with no consideration for customers, such as Bennett, who get in their way. “They assemble, they do whatever it is that they’re going to do, and then they disassemble in a matter of minutes,”

Message.Title: Where is the outrage
Message.Msg: From our pals on the left, it appears as long as it is a Obama drone...no problem. Those pesky Americans won't have to worry about the Patriot Act or being water boarded, they just get dead. **even if there is no intelligence indicating they are engaged in an active plot to attack the U.S.** Justice Department memo reveals legal case for drone strikes on Americans NBC News: A confidential Justice Department memo concludes that the U.S. government can order the killing of American citizens if they are believed to be “senior operational leaders” of al-Qaida or “an associated force” -- even if there is no intelligence indicating they are engaged in an active plot to attack the U.S. The 16-page memo, a copy of which was obtained by NBC News, provides new details about the legal reasoning behind one of the Obama administration’s most secretive and controversial polices: its dramatically increased use of drone strikes against al-Qaida suspects abroad, including those aimed at American citizens, such as the September 2011 strike in Yemen that killed alleged al-Qaida operatives Anwar al-Awlaki and Samir Khan. Both were U.S. citizens who had never been indicted by the U.S. government nor charged with any crimes.

Topic.Title: engineered inflation and cap gaisn tax increase makes stocks generational loser

Message.Msg: Heh, I bailed on the market and bought enough acreage to sustain myself and my wife for some time to come. That was in 2007, as I pulled about 75% of my equity out of my account due to the impending nomination of the current sitting President. I reinvested in 2009 after he'd done the worst of the damage he was likely to do, but I did so slowly accelerating gradually. Not until recently (2011) have I began to invest more aggressively, and that only because nothing BUT aggressive investing will keep you above water when living on a fixed income. Like the guy in the article said, inflation is a real serious #$%$, and you really really have to try to keep it beat. Some in land, some in improving the land, some in metals (that you have, not bits of paper), some in weapons (and ammunition, or arrows, whatever), some in tools, mostly tools that you would need to make the tools needed to survive in a subsistence culture, and of course the rest in a mishmash of financial instruments, cash, and most importantly, holding NO high interest debt. That's the sort of thing I'm going for. Though I think I still have one item of high interest debt yet, as one of my godsons conned me into co-signing on his truck for him . . . . (not gonna do THAT again). And I got hosed in 2012, something like $5,500 in realized losses (Thanks Radio Shack!). Absent that bum trade I'd have made about 4k.
